decision.reasoning: Seahawks regular season stats show dominance: 339 total first downs (125 rush, 179 pass, 35 pen) vs opponents' 291 (83 rush, 176 pass, 32 pen), indicating superior overall production especially in rushing (125 vs 83). Third down efficiency 82/206 (~39.8%). However, Patriots playoff performance is superior and more relevant: 3-0 with wins 16-3 vs Chargers (dominant D), 28-16 vs Texans (balanced), 10-7 vs Broncos (elite D in low-scoring grinder). Patriots boast league-best explosive creation rate 13.6% on offense, +2.8% success rate (4th in NFL), and Maye MVP-caliber with 17.3% tight-window throws (4th among QBs). Seahawks have best explosive-play differential (+4.7%), but Pats' playoff pedigree, defensive grit in close games, and explosive upside undervalue them at 38.6%. Market overrates Seahawks' regular-season edge; stats scream value on Pats in high-stakes SB.

decision.reasoning: Strong steel-man, but contrarian case not compelling enough to override stats. FPI gap massive (Sea 7.0 vs Pats 2.6)‚Äîtranslates to ~65-70% Sea win prob (aligns with Vegas -4.5/-230). Sea #1 def stifles Pats run (21st DVOA), forces predictable passes into top unit. Pats pass strength real but Sea allowed explosives once (to injured Rams); regular Sea bend-don't-break elite. Playoff D sample small (compromised foes). Darnold's "best game" outlier‚Äîregression risk. Market at 57.5% Sea < Vegas 65-70%, so YES undervalued, not overpriced. Herd bias possible but stats (FPI, rankings) confirm Sea edge. My net NO position already; time to adjust aggressively toward data.
decision.raw:
<contrarian_case>
The Patriots bull case is compelling and undervalued at 42.5% implied odds:

- **Elite passing offense vs. vulnerable Seahawks secondary**: Pats rank 3rd in overall DVOA, 2nd in Pass DVOA, 1st in EPA/dropback and Success Rate (59%). Seahawks def (#1 overall) allowed 12 explosives to Rams in NFC Champ‚ÄîPats have generated explosives efficiently all year and can exploit this in one-on-one matchups.

- **Playoff-tested Pats defense**: Ordinary regular-season advanced metrics, but allowed just 6 explosives over 3 postseason games vs. compromised offenses. Strategy: conservative shells, force Sea to run (Pats 9th vs run), live with FGs from Darnold (oblique history). Pats red-zone def weakness mitigated if they prevent drives from reaching it.

- **QB health edge**: Drake Maye full participant, shoulder "all good," no limitations. Darnold nursed oblique into playoffs‚Äîsusceptible to mistakes under pressure from Sea's deep pass rush (5 players >40 pressures).

- **Market blind spots**: AI herd anchored on Sea FPI (#1 vs #10), ignoring Pats offensive efficiency and playoff D improvement. Vegas spread -4.5 (-230 ML ~70% Sea) but sharp money on Pats +190 ML shows pro respect. Information cascade overlooks Pats road to SB (underdogs thriving). Vrabel coaching + Pats OL doesn't need perfection vs. Sea rush depth.

- **Key stats tilt**: Pats 9th offense/11th def vs. Sea 11th off/1st def‚Äîcloser matchup than FPI suggests. Pats can win low-scoring grinder (O/U 45.5), Maye TDs seal it. At 42.5%, NO offers +EV vs. Vegas-implied 30-35%.
</contrarian_case>

<reasoning>
Strong steel-man, but contrarian case not compelling enough to override stats. FPI gap massive (Sea 7.0 vs Pats 2.6)‚Äîtranslates to ~65-70% Sea win prob (aligns with Vegas -4.5/-230). Sea #1 def stifles Pats run (21st DVOA), forces predictable passes into top unit. Pats pass strength real but Sea allowed explosives once (to injured Rams); regular Sea bend-don't-break elite. Playoff D sample small (compromised foes). Darnold's "best game" outlier‚Äîregression risk. Market at 57.5% Sea < Vegas 65-70%, so YES undervalued, not overpriced. Herd bias possible but stats (FPI, rankings) confirm Sea edge. My net NO position already; time to adjust aggressively toward data.
</reasoning>
